physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. “Aldington” is written in pencil at the top of the first page. On the second page, “Mr. Aldington – 2” is typed in the upper right header. There are slight tears in the paper on the right sides of both pages.

div.p: Here is our bi-yearly pittance from the Imagist Anthologies. It gets smaller and smaller but never seems to stop entirely. However, as they have only a few copies on hand of each year and we have long ago given orders not to reprint, I think any time it may cease altogether.

I took the liberty of giving a letter to you to a young friend of mine the other day. His name is Royall Snow, and he is one of the Rhodes scholars. He has just sailed for England, and was to do a little tripping round the continent before he settled at Oxford. He will probably present his letter some time during the Winter. He writes poetry and prose; his interest is in creation; his faculty is for criticism. I have never been able to see much in his poems, but don't tell him I said so. He is now writing a novel, I believe. His criticism is really good and has appeared in the “New Republic” and elsewhere. He was very anxious to meet you because he admires you very much, and I thought you would not object to my giving him a letter. He is a most highly educated young person, having graduated summa cum laude from Harvard, and he has been teaching in universities for the two years since he has left college. Last year he was assistant professor of English at Dalhousie University, Halifax.

This reminds me of Eliot and your request. I am awfully sorry, dear Richard, I know just how you must hate me, but I cannot like your new
plan even as well as I liked your old. I regard it as a strategic blunder, and I cannot help thinking that you will do Mr. Eliot more harm than good in the eyes of the public; therefore, I still feel that I cannot go in with you. I may be wrong, I may bitterly regret it in the future, I may change my mind, but that is the way I feel about it now.
